messageBody:
Greetings,
On a totally different note...

One of the things mentioned as a solution in the other
thread I started (mea culpa), was mock objects. I'm
familiar with the idea, have written several, and for
simple things it makes some sense, but people talk
about them as if they're much more useful than I see
them as.

This is an area that I really don't know very well,
having only written a few 'mock objects', most of
which ended up having *frustratingly* high levels
of complexity themselves, just for test objects.
An example is a database mock I put together.
I was able to make it mostly work (querying a
list of 'n' most recent entries, for example, was a
pain), but it required a good bit of debugging, and
it ended up being nearly as complex as the actual
database class (and more so, in some cases, when
I needed to test getting data in various orders
which is super-easy in SQL, and annoyingly hard
when you have to implement it yourself.)

It gets worse when you're trying to mock one of
your own classes, still under active development.
As the interface changes, from refactoring, or just
new aspects, the mock has to change also, as well
as the tests. And sometimes you have to figure out
how to even implement the new interface parts in
the mock, if at all possible.

If all you're doing is returning a single value, then
you can't reasonably test, 'get next' type calls, or
anything like that. You need to add state to your
mock, and *poof* you've gotten into a situation
where your mock is nearly as complex as the real
thing.

How the heck do people mock things like database
access classes, mail servers, arbitrary web requests,
etc., without writing a huge amount of logic?

What am I missing?

-- Morgan Schweers
